Award.AwardTitle: Phase I Site Addition: I/UCRC for Multi-Functional Integrated System Technology (MIST) Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves a site addition of University of Virginia (UVA) to the Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Multifunctional Integrated Systems Technology (MIST). The semiconductor industry is grappling with the end of Moore's Law and a slow-down in electronic scaling for conventional digital logic. However, there is evidence of a parallel expansion into new domains such as unconventional computing and embedded applications. In particular the Internet of Things (IoT) promises by 2020 to connect up to 30 billion smart devices, buildings, vehicles and cities embedded with software, sensors and electronics that can exchange data and react in real time. While there is a lot of effort in IoT applications at the software level, the focus of this center is to develop the hardware base for the IoT. This includes five research thrusts ? computing, wireless, power, sensing and integration. The UVA site proposes to add new expertise in functional materials, solid-state devices, photonics, Terahertz sensing, thermal characterization, multiscale modeling and heterogeneous integration. Pre-competitive research in this area will serve industry interests by demonstrating proof-of-concept low power sensors and devices, enable cutting edge scientific and technological research, provide a platform for students to present research and facilitate recruitment, and target minority students through workshops geared towards industry internship.

The UVA Phase I site addition to the IUCRC center for Multifunctional Integrated Systems Technology (MIST) will focus on pre-competitive industry relevant research for smart systems innovations in the IoT era. This includes five research thrusts computing, wireless, power, sensing and integration ? targeting overall the hardware base for the IoT. This will need scalable and embedded applications with small Size-Weight and Power (SWaP), typically involving heterogeneous integration of materials, and integration of a large signal bandwidth from Terahertz and RF-photonic detection to Gigahertz for electronic processors. The UVA site proposes to add critical expertise towards integrated detector-processor arrays, including functional materials, solid-state devices, photonics, Terahertz sensing, thermal characterization, multiscale modeling and material integration. Research in this area will serve industry interests by demonstrating proof-of-concept low power sensors and devices, enable cutting edge scientific and technological research, provide a platform for students to present research and facilitate recruitment, and target minority students through workshops geared towards industry internship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Founded in 2014, the Multi-functional Integrated System Technology (MIST) Center ended a successful Phase 1 of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) program in 2019. The MIST Center, with its three sites at the University of Florida (UF), University of Central Florida (UCF), and University of Virginia (UVA joined in year 4 in 2017), share a common vision “to innovate More than Moore hardware technologies for smart systems in the IoT era.”  Its focus is on multi-functional hardware for the Smart-X IoT node with research structured around five requisite technology thrust areas: sensing, computing, wireless, power, and integration. 

Figure 1. MIST Center strategic thrust areas

The MIST Center strategic roadmap—developed closely with its industry advisory board (IAB)—is shown in Fig. 2.  Technology research efforts (five thrust areas) enable innovative solutions and platforms in the areas of wearables, IoT, sensor networks, and mist computing.  These system technologies are leveraged by IAB members in their market “pull” areas of automotive, healthcare, consumer/computing, aerospace/defense, agricultural, environment, and other industries. 

Figure 2. MIST Center strategic roadmap.

The MIST Center is funded by a combination of support from NSF, the University sites, and annual membership fees from member organizations. The membership fee is $50,000 ($25,000 for companies with less than 200 employees). The Center uses a federated funding model, where companies purchase membership at at least one university site, but that membership grants access to the entire Center research and IP portfolio. Approximately 94% of the membership fees are used to directly support research of interest to the member organizations (UF charged zero IDC on membership fees). All project awards are made in one-year increments using the calendar year. In 2019 (Year 5), members enjoyed a 20:1 return on investment (i.e. $50,000 in membership enables access to $988,000 of center research). Fig. 3 illustrates key milestones achieved by the MIST Center: 17 member organizations (+2 alumni), $3M in direct research expenditures (71 projects over five years), 79 pre-publication submissions to the industry advisory board, 12 invention disclosures (6 patents licensed), 88 graduate students, 61 undergraduates, and three participating universities. 


Figure 3. Phase 1 by the numbers

The broader impact of this research focuses on building collaborative multi-organization research networks, pre-collegiate and undergraduate educational/training activities, and broadening the diversity of all research participants. The I/UCRC framework naturally catalyzes significant collaborations between university and industry/government partners.  The Center also synergizes and inspires research collaboration between the university sites. The interdisciplinary, experimental nature of the MIST Center research portfolio provides significant opportunity for undergraduate and pre-collegiate training. UF has leveraged NSF REU supplements to support 8 undergraduate research students (including 3 female, 2 Hispanic, 1 African American) who have worked on MIST Center research. Starting in 2014, UF also started the ''MIST Makers,'' an undergraduate group mentored by MIST Center faculty to develop IoT prototypes using off-the-shelf hardware.  In this past year, the team designed and tested low-cost, user-serviceable, internet-connected weather stations for deployment in Haiti. Additionally, we have supported 2 high school student research experiences via UF's Summer Science Technology Program (SSTP).  We will continue broadening participation by targeted recruiting of female and URM students at all levels. UVA MIST site co-sponsored a major outreach activity as part of a community engagement event in Charlottesville, Virginia together with Rolls Royce and UVA, that provided children an opportunity to explore various vehicles. More than 2,000 people showed up. Working with UVA’s Center for Engineering Career Development, CERDEC NVESD organized a career fair on Feb 7 with 55 student attendees and selected three interns for the summer, and two potential hires going through the interview process, and engaged two additional students for interview to a company. UVA signed on with Websedge to produce a 5 minute advertisement film for MRS TV (Fig. 6) on MIST effort on campus that was broadcast at MRS Fall meeting, and internationally thereafter. Aside from coverage of UVA facilities such as the Multifunctional Materials Integration (MMI), NanoMaterials  Characterization Facility (NMCF) and UVA Microfabrication Lab (UVML), interviews were conducted with Avik Ghosh – UVA site Director of MIST, Patrick Hopkins – UVA site co-director, Pamela Norris – Executive Dean of UVA School of Engineering and Applied Science, Petra Reinke – director of the MMI effort, Arthur Lichtenberger – director of UVML, Shelby Powell – coordinator of entire MIST 3-university center, and James Howe – director of NMCF. This effort served as a model for subsequent videos that UF and UCF are now in the process of filming. Video is on UVA Engineering’s Youtube site
